Award.AwardTitle: A Micro/Nano-Scale Manufacturing Course-Module Aimed at Addressing the Technological Relevance of the Undergraduate Manufacturing Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing a novel three-week manufacturing course module focused on introducing cutting-edge research results in the area of micro-nanoscale manufacturing as part of existing undergraduate courses in the area of manufacturing and design. The explicit objective of the modules is to challenge the current perceptions of undergraduate students regarding the area of manufacturing by exposing them to the exciting education and research opportunities offered by advanced manufacturing technologies.

The courseware is centered on three distinct advanced manufacturing processes. The processes are chosen because they characterize the unique interplay of manufacturing science, material science and control systems and therefore can be introduced into a number of courses related to any of these areas.

The work is a collaborative effort between a research intensive university, a two-year community college, and a predominately Native American serving four year institution.

This project is producing an affective change in the mindset of undergraduate students towards the area of manufacturing; encouraging them in further study of the subject. The work is also producing curricular materials that can be used in a number of universities nationwide. To demonstrate this, project evaluators are measuring student cognitive and affective changes that are expected using a pre-post assessment. Evaluators are also collecting data to determine the project's transportability and utility for remote learning.

The project is contributing to the community's understanding of how to increase student interest for a subject by using technical research results combined with sound pedagogical methods. It is also contributing to the understanding of distance learning and transporting curriculum materials to a variety of venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This project resulted in the development of a novel manufacturing course-module geared towards introducing cutting-edge research in the area of micro/nano-scale manufacturing, as part of existing undergraduate courses in the areas of manufacturing and design. The module is centered on three distinct advanced manufacturing processes, viz., micro-machining, electrohydrodynamic-jet (E-jet) and electrospinning (E-spinning) that operate at the micron, sub-micron and nano-scales, respectively. In addition to these processes, curricular content was also developed in the areas of (i) cooling/lubrication in micro-machining, and (ii) process planning for additive manufacturing.  The module format consisting of a process-specific lecture followed by a hands-on laboratory exercise, has been effectively integrated into the existing undergraduate curriculum at both Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI), a four-year research university, and at Hudson Valley Community College (HVCC), a two-year community college, located in upstate New York.  As of May 2017, a total of 206 students (136 at RPI and 70 at HVCC) have benefited from this module. One key aspect of this collaboration between the two institutions is the “co-located educational-space model” where RPI maintains the high-end equipment infrastructure, while HVCC students have access to the space and the resources of the RPI teaching team. In addition, we have also demonstrated the transportability of our module by developing an online version of the micro-machining lab for use by remote academic institutions. This online module meets the learning objectives of the physical lab module, without the burden of acquiring and maintaining the expensive lab equipment.

 The assessment data collected across the RPI and HVCC student demographic reveals that: 1) The module has a positive impact on the students and their perceptions on advanced manufacturing in the United States  ; 2) The hands-on version of the module is more suitable for younger students (freshman and sophomores),  while the online version appear to be more suited for the upperclassman students who have experience with problem-solving and do not need the constant interaction with a teaching assistant; and (iii) The online version lacks the “hands-on” aspect that some students value in learning about manufacturing, but it does provide the analytical tools and calculations that are also important to understanding any manufacturing process. These assessment findings will guide the changes to be made to the module as the RPI-HVCC partnership continues past the timeframe of this NSF project.

 Broader Impact: 

The broader impact of this project is aimed at addressing the human resource crunch faced by the advanced manufacturing sector in the United States. Two-year community colleges and four-year universities provide the bulk of the human resource talent needed by the Nation’s manufacturing sector. In addition to being relevant to the training of the next generation of manufacturing professionals, micro/nano-scale technologies are also strategic in painting a positive picture of manufacturing for the youth in the United States. The RPI-HVCC partnership in this project proves that the geographical proximity of educational institutions, coupled with their complementary student demographic and mission in terms of manufacturing research and education, can result in a symbiotic relationship that promotes the cause of advanced manufacturing in the United States. Our multi-institution model for introducing micro/nano-scale manufacturing processes into the undergraduate curriculum can be applied across various universities including minority-serving colleges and two-year community colleges.  The implementation of such course modules will enable the funneling of undergraduates into the exciting careers offered by the advanced manufacturing section in the United States. In terms of human resource development, this project provided opportunities for the training and development of nine student researchers (3 PhD and 6 MEng.). While some of them are currently continuing their graduate degrees, others have been hired in the manufacturing sector by Sandia National Laboratories, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Ping Inc., United Technologies Corporation (UTC), and RBC Bearings. (Note: All curricular materials can be accessed at the central repository housed at https://rpimanufacturingoutreach.wordpress.com/. )
